Star Trek Online is not my favorite game, but it is my favorite Star Trek game. It‚Äôs the only title that truly captures the breadth of the franchise: space combat, away missions, shuttle runs, and high-concept storylines that feel like an episode brought to life. The developers‚Äô care shows in details big and small, whether it‚Äôs securing the original actors for their roles, subtle atmosphere in places like Deep Space 9, or expanding into stories drawn from Trek novels and comics. In those moments, it‚Äôs the most immersive Star Trek experience available.

But as a game, it struggles. Its monetization model is absurd at times, with some items priced beyond even AAA standards. The engine shows its age: this is a 15-year-old MMO, and it looks and feels like one. Performance can be frustrating, with rubber-banding mid-combat being a daily thing. Balance is shaky at best: power creep runs rampant, and there‚Äôs effectively no stable ‚Äúmeta‚Äù to speak of. Most sessions wear thin after an hour of repetitive gameplay.

So here‚Äôs the truth: Star Trek Online is not the best game you‚Äôll play, but it is the best way to live inside Star Trek. For all its flaws, no other title lets you step so completely into that universe, craft your own captain and crew, and chart a course through stories that feel like they belong in the canon.

I normally do not like MMO's. I played this game when it first came out many years ago and did not like it. There is a solid character and crew development scheme. And as with all things star trek, the characters, stories, and mechanics are true to the star trek genre. Purity, of course, is key.

So far it feels nice and gentle, not overstimulating with thousands of information and things to do and look at all of a sudden. Decent graphics, loving the story mode feeling mixed with massive roleplaying.

Look, this point this game is fairly casual for an MMO. I pick it up again every few years and play through the new content (usually relearning the whole game because I forgot how it works in the extended time away) until I get bored and put it on the shelf for another few years.

Yes, its "free." Yes, it can be grindy. Yes, There is so many different systems that trying to keep everything running can seem like you log in just to refresh duty missions ans such. BUT. And here is a good but: It's fun and totally gives players the ability to get into only as much as they care too.

Be the casual, only log on for play with friend times. Be a solo and play it like a single player game. Grind away at events and get a ton of free premium crap (It is grindy to get stuff, but if you are enjoying playing the game a bunch, you tend to just earn stuff as a matter of course). Or, be super sweaty and min/max the heck out of your Epic Gear that you spend untold hours shooting Borg drones to get.

This game is 15 years old, and they are still adding new content. Where they used to have to chart their own narrative course due to a dearth of Star Trek; the newer content does a decent job of incorporating storylines from the new shows into the existing STO cannon.

As a long-time Star Trek fan, I've seen my share of games that have tried to capture the magic of the franchise, but none have done it quite like Star Trek Online (STO). Despite being over a decade old, this game continues to be a vibrant and engaging experience that truly feels like you're stepping into the Star Trek universe.

What sets STO apart is its incredible dedication to the source material. The game's story, which has expanded into an epic saga, feels like a genuine, high-stakes television series. You'll encounter beloved characters from every era of Trek, voiced by the original actors, and explore iconic locations from the Alpha, Beta, Delta, and even Gamma Quadrants. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the ship designs to the sound effects, everything feels authentic.

The gameplay loop is incredibly satisfying. Ground combat is a fun mix of tactical abilities and phaser blasts, and the space combat is, for me, the highlight of the game. It's not just a chaotic brawl; it's a strategic dance of positioning, managing power levels, and using your ship's unique abilities. Nothing beats the feeling of successfully executing a classic "Trek-style" maneuver to outsmart a Klingon Bird-of-Prey or a Borg cube.

But beyond the mechanics, what truly makes Star Trek Online special is its community. There's a genuine sense of camaraderie and cooperation, especially within Fleets. It's a game where players work together to complete missions, build up their starbases, and share their love for the franchise. The developers, Cryptic Studios, have done an amazing job of keeping the content fresh with regular updates, new episodes, and exciting events.

Whether you're a veteran captain or a fresh-faced ensign, there's something for everyone in Star Trek Online. It's a game that respects its fans and the legacy of Star Trek, offering a deep, rewarding experience that you can get lost in for hundreds of hours. If you've ever dreamed of commanding your own starship, exploring strange new worlds, and boldly going where no one has gone before, then STO is the game for you. I can't recommend it enough. Live long and prosper!

negative.review:
I am willing to change my feedback if, and will say with a big IF, Deca or whoever took ownership of this game, will change the direction of STO to what is supposed to be: a Star Trek game, with exploration, contacts, and other intriguing missions rather than a Cash Grab game.

I have 800 hours on this account, but I did play STO even before (out of Steam) when the top tier ship was the Fleet one, and I played it until the Odyssey was released for the first time as a free ship. No strange weapons combination, the meta was anti-proton damage and the ESD map was, basically, square. 

The game changed a lot during the years in what it is now considered as a cash grabbing / FOMO game. Whales are keeping the game alive without even considering they are damaging the game rather than helping it to stay alive. I understand perfectly this is the only Star Trek game worth to be considered nowadays, which other ST game allows you to create your on Character, your own Crew, and fly your own ship (from the tons you have in there) and customising the equipment? It's great in that sense, and also the graphic and visuals are outstanding.

But, similar to other games, STO is ten miles wide and one inch deep. Klingon original story campaign, as well as the Romulan and Cardassian one, have been revamped and shrunk, to align to the needs of the story of the 24xx era. Clusters have been removed and replaced with Duty Officer missions. Reputations are a tedious farm to get something small in return because, yes, the best components/weapons/ships are from the Store or from the Lockboxes, which means cash grabbing. Don't get me wrong, you can still accomplish lot's of stuff in this game without even paying a penny, but the amount of ships they are throwing at you recently on the Store, is a pathetic way to monetise. 

But funs will criticise you the moment you say something negative against this game. For them, STO is a church, something sacred that cannot be criticised. That's the current status of the game.

I love Star Trek, I used to love a lot STO and I hope it will last forever, but if things won't change, this game will be only targeted towards whales that throw money at the 100th Miranda re-skin without a second thought.

Would recommend as a free game only. When you get the life time membership they will start to harass you.This game is under a new game studio and these guys are scam artists. Good game but don't trust your personal account info with these people.

Star Trek Online is something you can enjoy, but you should also consider its value.

As a fan of the Star Trek universe, you're guaranteed to find something you like here.

The possibilities are there, but not accessible to everyone.

There are tons of starships from all over the galaxy, a large number of story missions with excellent voice acting, and a wide variety of customization options for your captain, bridge officers, and ship.

On top of that, there are PvE and PvP events, seasonal events, fleets with bases, different factions, and much more.

So basically, it's a complete package for all Trekkies.

However, we also have to consider the Gorn in the room: 
FOMO, gacha, pay2win, bugs, and slow hotfixes (if they happen at all).

I'm not someone you can just milk, but I've met many players who, without hesitation, shell out a hundred euros for a ship bundle just to get a single, specific console.

And that's insane, because it's profiting off the backs of people who are ultimately being blackmailed.

It's about maximizing digital "performance," hidden behind a massive paywall.

If it were just about cosmetics, it wouldn't be so problematic in my eyes, but these are items that significantly impact the gameplay experience.

And if enough people have purchased the package, a small patch will often be released to mitigate the "accidentally" overpowered item... 
What a surprise!

The rabbit hole you can climb here is deep if you're looking for optimizing your experience.

Very, very deep.

I mean - watch some videos about top tier builds.

And now, after 15 years of STO, I have to say that the still clunky interface, the truly awful character animations, the disproportionately expensive items in the shop, the terrible communication from the developers (last Steam post from April 25, 2017), the bugs that have persisted for years, the pay-to-win mechanics, and much more,
show how little respect they really have for the fan and player community.

/peace

This is like a mobile game, it even has fake currency you can buy with real money to speed up your in game progress. The actual gameplay is very bad. The Dialogue is set, no choices. In fact you never get any choices. You walk around and press F, to activate the thing. Then either watch a video or shoot at some guys who are never a threat. You barely aim, as long as your pointed in the general direction of the bad guy you'll hit them. The ship combat you don't aim at all. You can fly around but there's no point. Just keep clicking the weapon buttons till you win. If you ever die that doesn't matter, just respawn exactly where you died, as many times as you want. The graphics are raw and unfinished. The is no problem solving or exploration at all. You travel across a space map to each mission, but you can't use the holodeck or go to 10 forward or anything during the trip. Just sit and wait 1-5 minutes. 

I'm not sure what this is. It does have 3D game elements in it. But you click a button to win. The dialogue doesn't actually matter but can at least give you a Star Trek feeling. But there's no tension, no skill, no new stories, no good writing, no good anything. this is an absolute ZERO effort game that really can't even be called a game. With that said I haven't completely uninstalled yet, but it's hard to take in more than 20 minute segments at a time. It's really really bad even to someone who's watched every episode 20 times.

But, similar to other games, STO is ten miles wide and one inch deep. Klingon original story campaign, as well as the Romulan and Cardassian one, have been revamped and shrunk, to align to the needs of the story of the 24xx era. Don't get me wrong, you can still accomplish lot's of stuff in this game without even paying a penny, but the amount of ships they are throwing at you recently on the Store, is a pathetic way to monetise.

I pre-ordered the Collector's Edition. While I'm not the biggest Star Trek fan, I agree with others that STO may be the best Trek game out there - unfortunately, that says more about the state of Trek gaming than anything. I haven't played much since 2012, but I pop my head in every few years because the space combat is addicting. 

I would prefer not to downvote this game, but unfortunately, it has some significant issues that cannot be overlooked:

[list]
    [*]It is a 15-year old MMORPG. Like all older MMOs, the newer content looks good with better animations and higher resolution textures. But, when bumped up against older content and models, they stand out. This is universal with all MMOs. 
    [*]Ground combat sucks. It sucked in 2010 and especially in 2025. Cryptic attempted to "modernize" it over the years, but it's not great. Space combat is amazing - even non-Trek fans should enjoy it. 
    [*]STO's monetization strategy makes mobile games blush. End game ships run $25-30 each. Bundles of ships with additional perks are $100+. Many players justify these costs - if you're devoting dozens or hundreds of hours a year, it may balance out. To the more casual fan, it does not. [b]Remember:[/b] There is no subscription for STO. It's F2P or Zen store. 
[/list]

[h3] My Recommendation [/h3]
Try it out. Level up some characters. There are some free T6 (end game) ships available through events - although they're a slugfest to get and likely not the "cool ones," that you may want. Since it is F2P, it doesn't hurt to try.

99% Dps, near zero skill based combat. Some ships have amazing detail, others look like something out of the N64 generation (really annoying when the ship with the right gameplay-features has textures that would make last century look like the future). Furthermore, the level scaling is outright unfair. Never in my life have I 
played a game where I've dreaded leveling up more than in this game. At a certain point you are forced into using the crafting system as the current enemies are to powerful for any gear you can buy with your basic currency. Now that wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't for the fact that BY THE TIME YOU HAVE GOT THE ITEMS REQUIRED TO CRAFT YOU KIT, IT'S ALREADY OUTDATED!

In the beginning this game was extremely fun and entertaining, but it became confusing, complicated and tedious, its behind a pay wall (Micro transactions), while I understand that an FTP game must make money some how, they are ridiculously expensive.  Trying to find out which phaser array goes with which build, and which crew goes best with what ship has become daunting and complicated.  Also if you enjoy doing the same boring missions over and over and over again, than this is your game.  Otherwise move on to another of the plethora of MMOs out there, that are far more entertaining, like Star Wars The Old Republic (SWTOR for short), its far less complicated, and far more fun.

Star Trek Online is something you can enjoy, but you should also consider its value.

As a fan of the Star Trek universe, you're guaranteed to find something you like here.

The possibilities are there, but not accessible to everyone.

There are tons of starships from all over the galaxy, a large number of story missions with excellent voice acting, and a wide variety of customization options for your captain, bridge officers, and ship.

On top of that, there are PvE and PvP events, seasonal events, fleets with bases, different factions, and much more.

So basically, it's a complete package for all Trekkies.

However, we also have to consider the Gorn in the room: 
FOMO, gacha, pay2win, bugs, and slow hotfixes (if they happen at all).

I'm not someone you can just milk, but I've met many players who, without hesitation, shell out a hundred euros for a ship bundle just to get a single, specific console.

And that's insane, because it's profiting off the backs of people who are ultimately being blackmailed.

It's about maximizing digital "performance," hidden behind a massive paywall.

If it were just about cosmetics, it wouldn't be so problematic in my eyes, but these are items that significantly impact the gameplay experience.

And if enough people have purchased the package, a small patch will often be released to mitigate the "accidentally" overpowered item... 
What a surprise!

The rabbit hole you can climb here is deep if you're looking for optimizing your experience.

Very, very deep.

I mean - watch some videos about top tier builds.

And now, after 15 years of STO, I have to say that the still clunky interface, the truly awful character animations, the disproportionately expensive items in the shop, the terrible communication from the developers (last Steam post from April 25, 2017), the bugs that have persisted for years, the pay-to-win mechanics, and much more,
show how little respect they really have for the fan and player community.

Star Trek Online is a basic fighting game well-dressed in Star Trek clothing, both Federation and Klingon factions must fight a lot, repeatedly. There are two ways to fight: personal combat (Ground) and spaceship combat (Space). Players can play against the computer‚Äôs programming (PvE) or against other players (PvP). Besides fighting, there are many social zones where players do not fight but may interact with other players in and out of context (RPG). The purpose of the game for players should be to have fun with the game and with each other, and this usually happens because of the friendly community! 

Some Star Trek fans and fans of space in general have their fun rooted in realism. However, this game is not an accurate simulation of either space or combat. It is more like an entertaining theme park with games and rides. Understanding this may adjust your expectations and result in having more fun while playing the game.

Some players have fun playing a game for free (F2P). This game is definitely F2P. Not only that, but there are regular giveaways, recurring events, and special occasions that provide opportunities for players to make the most of resources accrued. This will cost a player their time daily for years, but not their money, and keep them coming back to reset timers. However, players who wish to save time and avoid repeating or ‚Äúgrinding,‚Äù may pay for their character‚Äôs advancement in various ways, including game-like mechanics resembling gambling mechanisms. The depth and cost of in-game purchases is vast, and a player may eventually find themselves repeating or ‚Äúgrinding‚Äù with their money just as much as a F2P player would with their time! It is recommended to have fun within your means rather than ‚Äúgrind‚Äù too much. Nevertheless, the game is very good at tempting players who enjoy it to make at least occasional purchases. In fact, some F2P players actually have a separate account that is definitely not F2P! So there can be some fun in progressing a F2P account, to see how well you can do for free. With some out-of-game research, anyone can make a reasonably fun character that can do fairly well in both PvE and PvP matches.


Reality versus Fantasy

Many things about Star Trek Online are different than Star Trek as represented in other media and real life. Some of this is deliberate to make the game easier to play; some of this is unavoidable because of the game engine itself.

For example, we rarely see personal shield generators when Star Trek characters engage in Ground combat, except for the Borg. However, in Star Trek Online, personal shield generators are standard equipment for players and their bridge crew. This is necessary to allow for fighting, since this is a fighting game; there would be no fight if everyone was actually afraid to die from a weapon‚Äôs first fatal blow! Star Trek Online also allows players to respawn in the event of incapacitation or destruction, costing the player‚Äôs team valuable time.

Distances and zone-of-controls are standardized and considerably reduced in both Ground and Space combat. For example virtually all weapons have the same effective range, and zone-of-controls ignore potential sensor ranges and even line-of-sight until trespassed! This, of course, detracts from realism but contributes to ease of play.

Space combat is more like aerial hover-drone combat and not at all like space combat should be, but this is a limitation of the game engine, which was never designed to simulate three-dimensional movement in open space. For example, spaceships cannot change their horizon with partial rolls and are limited by finite pitch within an invisible room with a hidden floor and ceiling. There is no free inertia countered by acceleration and deceleration or vectored thrust, and no orbiting stellar bodies. These along with the above mentioned standardized and reduced distances break any thrill of simulation. However, these limitations actually make the game easier and quicker to play for most who want to ‚Äúgrind‚Äù and represent fairly what viewers have seen in televised representations of Star Trek.


Tactics and Strategy

The tactics of almost all content of this game revolves around defeating enemies in fights rather than avoiding them. To that end, there are a seemingly limitless number of different pieces of equipment offering various protections and offensive capabilities.

However, with regard to tactics none of all that really makes any difference. For example, it doesn‚Äôt really matter if you shoot with a phaser weapon or with a disruptor weapon, or any other type of weapon. A lot of things that you would think should make a big difference, such as terrain, weather, range, line-of-sight, mass, physics, are not really major considerations. That is because the technology of Star Trek Online has rendered these real-world considerations more-or-less moot.

Tactics, therefore, boils down to the ability to damage targets versus the target‚Äôs ability to absorb and heal damage. For PvE, the focus is usually on building a loadout that contributes what is needed for a team of players and maximizes damage per second, or DPS. This tactic attempts to destroy enemies before they can even pose a significant threat. With PvP, however, the focus is usually on survivability first and contributing to a team effort to reduce a competitor‚Äôs ability to heal and sustain damage and eventually destroy the competitor.

The real-world tactics in both Ground and Space, is in the gradual acquisition of better equipment and unlocking better abilities, and in the player‚Äôs‚Äînot the character‚Äôs‚Äîgradually learning what works and does not and how to do things such as run and fly. The better equipment is mostly the kit frame and modules for the Ground setting, and the bridge officer stations of a spaceship for the Space setting. As a consequence, the entire game actually revolves around constantly acquiring various in-game currencies to purchase better kit frames and kits and better spaceships with the best officer stations; and to upgrade them and all your other equipment that supports them. There is, however, a very steep learning curve and one could easily spend as many hours reading and watching fan-created content designed to inform players as one could spend actually playing the game. Not to mention that new content, including equipment, is continually created and added to the game!

As far as overall strategy on a grand scale, there is none that a player can affect for good or bad. The galaxy is static, set in stone. In the long run it does not matter to the galaxy if a player chooses to side with the Federation or Klingon faction. Despite eventually becoming an admiral, a player will make no decisions that affect grand strategy, though they will be labored with numerous repetitive administrative duties for rewards to help further levelling up and acquisition of in-game currencies. However, a player will play through story episodes and missions that role-play through great predestined galaxy-shaking events, along with many favorite Star Trek characters! To that end, there is a lot of story content that could be enjoyed for many, many hours, much of which is actually a pleasure to repeat once in a while.

In conclusion, if you want to forget reality for hours on end and enjoy a Star Trek fantasy theme park, if you want to research fan-created instructions, guides, and recommendations out of necessity, if you actually read this entire review to your benefit, then this game is recommended for you!

I would not recommend this game to anyone who is not a Star Trek fan. Outside the stories (which are pretty good) and seeing/interacting with characters from the series, this game doesn't have much going for it.

Pros: Interesting stories that keep you engaged, returning characters from the series who you often interact with, lots of customization (ships, ship designs, ship weapons, character weapons, characters, bridge crew, etc.)

Cons: Unacceptable bugs (audio overlapping, missions that need to be dropped and then picked back up because the story wont load necessary events, leaving a system and getting trapped within the 3D models of the stars [gotta leave and come back unless you transwarp], UI has incorrect overlapping screens [getting a coms call will still display the ship's shields and hull health over the coms call text for some reason]), confusing UI that tells you you can have more bridge crew (but you can't but you can [yeah, I'm just as confused as you]), waves of sponge enemies (seriously, this needs to stop. Nobody wants to play a clicking simulator. That's NOT fun), not enough save points (this is an online game, there NEEDS to be more save points to prevent massive wastes of time), overly complex and cluttered UI, overly complex literally everything else (I'm STILL getting tutorials after I'm over 20 hours in and I'm lost on what most of this is supposed to do because it's so overwhelming), monetized to heck and back, some tutorials come AFTER you've already dealt with the thing it's trying to teach you.

Overall, I think this game is okay, it's just marred by a lot of issues that just shouldn't be. If you're a Star Trek fan, you can probably push past all the jank and actually enjoy it.

Edit: Just tried out the events for the first time. Yikes. That wont be a mistake I make ever again.

Where to begin with this game.....Well, for starters, it doesn't seem to know what KIND of game it is. It's a Space Sim, no wait, it's a Space Tactics game, no wait, it's a 3PS with literally the worst controls and gameplay I've ever experienced, (and I lived through the MS-DOS era of gaming), no, now it wants to be an MMO! I get that Star Trek encompasses all of these genres, but this game seems to think that being terrible at most of them is better than being good at one of them.

Next, we get into the real hot-topic of this game being P2W. Without exception, it's 100% pay to win. The wait times for prizes are excessive, and you HAVE to buy keys to unlock these "prize boxes". So yes, it's pay to win or put more accurately: if you don't pay, you're going to respawn insanely often.

Let's also consider that the game has been in development for 15 years now. 15 years! And they still haven't figured out how to make ground combat manageable without having to click on (up to) 100 individual tiles. The graphics still meet the bare minimum definition of the word "graphics" as we knew it in 2015, and in 2025, there's just no excuse for loading issues and horrendous hit boxes anymore. I can't even get into the stupendously clunky control schemes without going into a full on rant about keyboard efficiency and effective gameplay.

Overall, I give this game a 3/10. It tried hard to give us the entire Star Trek experience, but only resulted in a 
pretty awful all around experience wrapped in a Pay 2 Win package that used fans' love of Star Trek to make absurd amounts of money. I feel bad for the OG Trek actors who provided their voices to this game, for being associated with a total scam. I also feel bad for Terry Matalas for giving this game a shout out (via the Enterprise F's cameo) in Picard Season 3. That was a huge shout out, Cryptic, the Enterprise F has been etched into Star Trek Canon now, and it comes back to this complete scam of a game. The fact that we have to live with the STO Enterprise F forever in Star Trek lore now is probably the thing that disgusts me the most about this game. The best season of Picard, the TNG comeback we've wanted for 20+ years, and it's sullied by Star Trek Online.
I prefer open world experiences to market bazaars and force-following quest markers.  It's not role playing if the role is played for me.

Star Trek Online is something you can enjoy, but you should also consider its value.

As a fan of the Star Trek universe, you're guaranteed to find something you like here.

The possibilities are there, but not accessible to everyone.

There are tons of starships from all over the galaxy, a large number of story missions with excellent voice acting, and a wide variety of customization options for your captain, bridge officers, and ship.

On top of that, there are PvE and PvP events, seasonal events, fleets with bases, different factions, and much more.

So basically, it's a complete package for all Trekkies.

However, we also have to consider the Gorn in the room: 
FOMO, gacha, pay2win, bugs, and slow hotfixes (if they happen at all).

I'm not someone you can just milk, but I've met many players who, without hesitation, shell out a hundred euros for a ship bundle just to get a single, specific console.

And that's insane, because it's profiting off the backs of people who are ultimately being blackmailed.

It's about maximizing digital "performance," hidden behind a massive paywall.

If it were just about cosmetics, it wouldn't be so problematic in my eyes, but these are items that significantly impact the gameplay experience.

And if enough people have purchased the package, a small patch will often be released to mitigate the "accidentally" overpowered item... 
What a surprise!

The rabbit hole you can climb here is deep if you're looking for optimizing your experience.

Very, very deep.

I mean - watch some videos about top tier builds.

And now, after 15 years of STO, I have to say that the still clunky interface, the truly awful character animations, the disproportionately expensive items in the shop, the terrible communication from the developers (last Steam post from April 25, 2017), the bugs that have persisted for years, the pay-to-win mechanics, and much more,
show how little respect they really have for the fan and player community.

/peace

Star Trek Online is a basic fighting game well-dressed in Star Trek clothing, both Federation and Klingon factions must fight a lot, repeatedly. There are two ways to fight: personal combat (Ground) and spaceship combat (Space). Players can play against the computer‚Äôs programming (PvE) or against other players (PvP). Besides fighting, there are many social zones where players do not fight but may interact with other players in and out of context (RPG). The purpose of the game for players should be to have fun with the game and with each other, and this usually happens because of the friendly community! 

Some Star Trek fans and fans of space in general have their fun rooted in realism. However, this game is not an accurate simulation of either space or combat. It is more like an entertaining theme park with games and rides. Understanding this may adjust your expectations and result in having more fun while playing the game.

Some players have fun playing a game for free (F2P). This game is definitely F2P. Not only that, but there are regular giveaways, recurring events, and special occasions that provide opportunities for players to make the most of resources accrued. This will cost a player their time daily for years, but not their money, and keep them coming back to reset timers. However, players who wish to save time and avoid repeating or ‚Äúgrinding,‚Äù may pay for their character‚Äôs advancement in various ways, including game-like mechanics resembling gambling mechanisms. The depth and cost of in-game purchases is vast, and a player may eventually find themselves repeating or ‚Äúgrinding‚Äù with their money just as much as a F2P player would with their time! It is recommended to have fun within your means rather than ‚Äúgrind‚Äù too much. Nevertheless, the game is very good at tempting players who enjoy it to make at least occasional purchases. In fact, some F2P players actually have a separate account that is definitely not F2P! So there can be some fun in progressing a F2P account, to see how well you can do for free. With some out-of-game research, anyone can make a reasonably fun character that can do fairly well in both PvE and PvP matches.


Reality versus Fantasy

Many things about Star Trek Online are different than Star Trek as represented in other media and real life. Some of this is deliberate to make the game easier to play; some of this is unavoidable because of the game engine itself.

For example, we rarely see personal shield generators when Star Trek characters engage in Ground combat, except for the Borg. However, in Star Trek Online, personal shield generators are standard equipment for players and their bridge crew. This is necessary to allow for fighting, since this is a fighting game; there would be no fight if everyone was actually afraid to die from a weapon‚Äôs first fatal blow! Star Trek Online also allows players to respawn in the event of incapacitation or destruction, costing the player‚Äôs team valuable time.

Distances and zone-of-controls are standardized and considerably reduced in both Ground and Space combat. For example virtually all weapons have the same effective range, and zone-of-controls ignore potential sensor ranges and even line-of-sight until trespassed! This, of course, detracts from realism but contributes to ease of play.

Space combat is more like aerial hover-drone combat and not at all like space combat should be, but this is a limitation of the game engine, which was never designed to simulate three-dimensional movement in open space. For example, spaceships cannot change their horizon with partial rolls and are limited by finite pitch within an invisible room with a hidden floor and ceiling. There is no free inertia countered by acceleration and deceleration or vectored thrust, and no orbiting stellar bodies. These along with the above mentioned standardized and reduced distances break any thrill of simulation. However, these limitations actually make the game easier and quicker to play for most who want to ‚Äúgrind‚Äù and represent fairly what viewers have seen in televised representations of Star Trek.


Tactics and Strategy

The tactics of almost all content of this game revolves around defeating enemies in fights rather than avoiding them. To that end, there are a seemingly limitless number of different pieces of equipment offering various protections and offensive capabilities.

However, with regard to tactics none of all that really makes any difference. For example, it doesn‚Äôt really matter if you shoot with a phaser weapon or with a disruptor weapon, or any other type of weapon. A lot of things that you would think should make a big difference, such as terrain, weather, range, line-of-sight, mass, physics, are not really major considerations. That is because the technology of Star Trek Online has rendered these real-world considerations more-or-less moot.

Tactics, therefore, boils down to the ability to damage targets versus the target‚Äôs ability to absorb and heal damage. For PvE, the focus is usually on building a loadout that contributes what is needed for a team of players and maximizes damage per second, or DPS. This tactic attempts to destroy enemies before they can even pose a significant threat. With PvP, however, the focus is usually on survivability first and contributing to a team effort to reduce a competitor‚Äôs ability to heal and sustain damage and eventually destroy the competitor.

The real-world tactics in both Ground and Space, is in the gradual acquisition of better equipment and unlocking better abilities, and in the player‚Äôs‚Äînot the character‚Äôs‚Äîgradually learning what works and does not and how to do things such as run and fly. The better equipment is mostly the kit frame and modules for the Ground setting, and the bridge officer stations of a spaceship for the Space setting. As a consequence, the entire game actually revolves around constantly acquiring various in-game currencies to purchase better kit frames and kits and better spaceships with the best officer stations; and to upgrade them and all your other equipment that supports them. There is, however, a very steep learning curve and one could easily spend as many hours reading and watching fan-created content designed to inform players as one could spend actually playing the game. Not to mention that new content, including equipment, is continually created and added to the game!

As far as overall strategy on a grand scale, there is none that a player can affect for good or bad. The galaxy is static, set in stone. In the long run it does not matter to the galaxy if a player chooses to side with the Federation or Klingon faction. Despite eventually becoming an admiral, a player will make no decisions that affect grand strategy, though they will be labored with numerous repetitive administrative duties for rewards to help further levelling up and acquisition of in-game currencies. However, a player will play through story episodes and missions that role-play through great predestined galaxy-shaking events, along with many favorite Star Trek characters! To that end, there is a lot of story content that could be enjoyed for many, many hours, much of which is actually a pleasure to repeat once in a while.

In conclusion, if you want to forget reality for hours on end and enjoy a Star Trek fantasy theme park, if you want to research fan-created instructions, guides, and recommendations out of necessity, if you actually read this entire review to your benefit, then this game is recommended for you!

I would not recommend this game to anyone who is not a Star Trek fan. Outside the stories (which are pretty good) and seeing/interacting with characters from the series, this game doesn't have much going for it.

Pros: Interesting stories that keep you engaged, returning characters from the series who you often interact with, lots of customization (ships, ship designs, ship weapons, character weapons, characters, bridge crew, etc.)

Cons: Unacceptable bugs (audio overlapping, missions that need to be dropped and then picked back up because the story wont load necessary events, leaving a system and getting trapped within the 3D models of the stars [gotta leave and come back unless you transwarp], UI has incorrect overlapping screens [getting a coms call will still display the ship's shields and hull health over the coms call text for some reason]), confusing UI that tells you you can have more bridge crew (but you can't but you can [yeah, I'm just as confused as you]), waves of sponge enemies (seriously, this needs to stop. Nobody wants to play a clicking simulator. That's NOT fun), not enough save points (this is an online game, there NEEDS to be more save points to prevent massive wastes of time), overly complex and cluttered UI, overly complex literally everything else (I'm STILL getting tutorials after I'm over 20 hours in and I'm lost on what most of this is supposed to do because it's so overwhelming), monetized to heck and back, some tutorials come AFTER you've already dealt with the thing it's trying to teach you.

Overall, I think this game is okay, it's just marred by a lot of issues that just shouldn't be. If you're a Star Trek fan, you can probably push past all the jank and actually enjoy it.

Edit: Just tried out the events for the first time. Yikes. That wont be a mistake I make ever again.

Where to begin with this game.....Well, for starters, it doesn't seem to know what KIND of game it is. It's a Space Sim, no wait, it's a Space Tactics game, no wait, it's a 3PS with literally the worst controls and gameplay I've ever experienced, (and I lived through the MS-DOS era of gaming), no, now it wants to be an MMO! I get that Star Trek encompasses all of these genres, but this game seems to think that being terrible at most of them is better than being good at one of them.

Next, we get into the real hot-topic of this game being P2W. Without exception, it's 100% pay to win. The wait times for prizes are excessive, and you HAVE to buy keys to unlock these "prize boxes". So yes, it's pay to win or put more accurately: if you don't pay, you're going to respawn insanely often.

Let's also consider that the game has been in development for 15 years now. 15 years! And they still haven't figured out how to make ground combat manageable without having to click on (up to) 100 individual tiles. The graphics still meet the bare minimum definition of the word "graphics" as we knew it in 2015, and in 2025, there's just no excuse for loading issues and horrendous hit boxes anymore. I can't even get into the stupendously clunky control schemes without going into a full on rant about keyboard efficiency and effective gameplay.

Overall, I give this game a 3/10. It tried hard to give us the entire Star Trek experience, but only resulted in a 
pretty awful all around experience wrapped in a Pay 2 Win package that used fans' love of Star Trek to make absurd amounts of money. I feel bad for the OG Trek actors who provided their voices to this game, for being associated with a total scam. I also feel bad for Terry Matalas for giving this game a shout out (via the Enterprise F's cameo) in Picard Season 3. That was a huge shout out, Cryptic, the Enterprise F has been etched into Star Trek Canon now, and it comes back to this complete scam of a game. The fact that we have to live with the STO Enterprise F forever in Star Trek lore now is probably the thing that disgusts me the most about this game. The best season of Picard, the TNG comeback we've wanted for 20+ years, and it's sullied by Star Trek Online.
It's just too old and janky.  It's free to play, but I would not recommend it.

I pre-ordered the Collector's Edition. While I'm not the biggest Star Trek fan, I agree with others that STO may be the best Trek game out there - unfortunately, that says more about the state of Trek gaming than anything. I haven't played much since 2012, but I pop my head in every few years because the space combat is addicting. 

I would prefer not to downvote this game, but unfortunately, it has some significant issues that cannot be overlooked:

[list]
    [*]It is a 15-year old MMORPG. Like all older MMOs, the newer content looks good with better animations and higher resolution textures. But, when bumped up against older content and models, they stand out. This is universal with all MMOs. 
    [*]Ground combat sucks. It sucked in 2010 and especially in 2025. Cryptic attempted to "modernize" it over the years, but it's not great. Space combat is amazing - even non-Trek fans should enjoy it. 
    [*]STO's monetization strategy makes mobile games blush. End game ships run $25-30 each. Bundles of ships with additional perks are $100+. Many players justify these costs - if you're devoting dozens or hundreds of hours a year, it may balance out. To the more casual fan, it does not. [b]Remember:[/b] There is no subscription for STO. It's F2P or Zen store. 
[/list]

[h3] My Recommendation [/h3]
Try it out. Level up some characters. There are some free T6 (end game) ships available through events - although they're a slugfest to get and likely not the "cool ones," that you may want. Since it is F2P, it doesn't hurt to try.

99% Dps, near zero skill based combat. Some ships have amazing detail, others look like something out of the N64 generation (really annoying when the ship with the right gameplay-features has textures that would make last century look like the future). Furthermore, the level scaling is outright unfair. Never in my life have I 
played a game where I've dreaded leveling up more than in this game. At a certain point you are forced into using the crafting system as the current enemies are to powerful for any gear you can buy with your basic currency. Now that wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't for the fact that BY THE TIME YOU HAVE GOT THE ITEMS REQUIRED TO CRAFT YOU KIT, IT'S ALREADY OUTDATED!

In the beginning this game was extremely fun and entertaining, but it became confusing, complicated and tedious, its behind a pay wall (Micro transactions), while I understand that an FTP game must make money some how, they are ridiculously expensive.  Trying to find out which phaser array goes with which build, and which crew goes best with what ship has become daunting and complicated.  Also if you enjoy doing the same boring missions over and over and over again, than this is your game.  Otherwise move on to another of the plethora of MMOs out there, that are far more entertaining, like Star Wars The Old Republic (SWTOR for short), its far less complicated, and far more fun.
